awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Algorithms in Computational Geometry and Medical Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern medical research and imaging technologies together present physicians and clinicians with mind-boggling amounts of detailed molecular or cellular structures. For example, one 2-dimensional image slide can contain millions of cells. In fact, pathologists use microscopes to examine only tens or hundreds of cells at a time, missing most cells, and also missing possible patterns in the intermediate range. This project addresses the need to study patterns in cell images through powerful computational and analytic techniques in computational geometry, and to validate these algorithmic techniques, and software built from them, in medical research and applications.  

The project formulates challenging geometric and algorithmic problems that emerge in the diagnosis, prognosis, and analysis of diseases (e.g., breast cancer, inflammatory bowel disease, and rheumatoid arthritis), identification and classification of different types of immune cells (e.g., neutrophils, eosinophils, plasma cells, and lymphocytes), and tracking and analysis of collectively moving and swarming bacteria (e.g., Myxococcus xanthus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa) in terms of a class of Voronoi diagrams (developed by the lead investigator) in which collections of cells influence nearby neighbors. Specific geometric techniques include clustering-induced Voronoi diagrams, coupled optimal shape approximation, and matching based on earth mover's distance.

Exploring these geometric structures in important medical problems will not only lead to new methods in combinatorial optimization and machine learning, and new publically-available software for medical applications, but also train students in the broad range of interdisciplinary research and education from geometric algorithms, software development, to medical applications. By providing appropriate analysis tools for the physicians, this project and its students will help save lives.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to study applied computational geometry problems and develop new algorithmic techniques and solutions for practical applications, especially in computational biomedicine and biomedical imaging. Also, the project sought to formulate and investigate a set of fundamental theoretical geometric computing problems, especially those that capture or model important applications, and to forge new geometric computing techniques, in order to strengthen the theoretical foundations of computational geometry and other theoretical computer science areas, and build connections with real applications. The project strived to develop and combine new algorithmic techniques and cutting-edge methods in applied areas (e.g., deep learning models) to tackle real application problems.

The project focused on formulating and solving challenging applied computational geometry problems in practical application areas, such as biomedicine (e.g., disease diagnosis and treatment), biomedical imaging, data mining, computer vision, visualization, and machine learning. Theoretically, the target applied problems belong to major geometric computing topics of significant generality and value, such as geometric partition, shaping approximation, path planning, Voronoi diagrams, covering, clustering, matching, and tracking. Practically, new geometric models and algorithmic approaches were developed for core problems in biomedical applications and clinical practice, such as pulmonary nodule detection, cervical dysplasia diagnosis, cardiovascular segmentation, pancreas segmentation, vertebra localization, real-time polyp segmentation, retinal vessel segmentation, ant dynamics tracking, and bacteria motion tracking.

The project developed many new algorithmic techniques and solutions for fundamental computational geometry problems, such as geometric shortest paths, visibility, Voronoi diagrams, geometric data structures, shape approximation, geometric partition, geometric packing, surface detection, geometric graph construction, geometric clustering, etc. The new algorithms obtained are more efficient than the previously best-known solutions for these problems. For example, new models of Voronoi diagrams based on sites of point clusters and influence functions, as well as their applications, were introduced and investigated, and new algorithmic techniques for computing such new Voronoi diagrams were developed. 

This project also studied a very large array of important problems in biomedical applications, such as biomedical imaging, disease diagnosis and analysis, and bioinformatics. These problems included biomedical image segmentation, classification, tracking, registration, and analysis, immune cell identification and classification, cell clustering, glial cell segmentation and analysis in brain microenvironments, brain metastasis of breast cancer, cervical dysplasia diagnosis, cardiovascular segmentation, 3D vertebra localization, pancreas segmentation, real-time polyp segmentation, 3D skull cartilage segmentation, retinal vessel segmentation, 3D knee joint segmentation, pulmonary nodule segmentation, label-free visualization and characterization of extracellular vesicles for breast cancer study, Drosophila wing disc segmentation and registration, massive bacteria motion tracking and analysis, ant motion tracking and analysis, GPU implementation of deep learning based biomedical imaging algorithms, embryonic and tissue segmentation, inversion detection and prediction, operon prediction, etc. New algorithms, which are much improved over the methods used in the current biomedical practice and in the biomedical literature, have been developed by this research. The research work found many applications in biomedical research and medical diagnosis, prognosis, analysis, and treatment. Consequently, the results have been published frequently in high quality computer science and biomedical journals and conferences.

The cell detection and analysis algorithms from this research were used in the studies of breast cancer. For example, the dendritic cell clustering method has been used in breast cancer analysis. This research developed new algorithms for identifying, tracking, and analyzing the motion and formation of massive swarms of bacteria, and the methods have been applied to bacteria studies. This work developed a new framework for studying brain metastasis of breast cancer and new algorithms for segmenting glial cells in 3D brain microenvironments. The research developed new deep learning based methods for tracking and analyzing the behaviors of ants in rain forests (to study their disease transmission patterns). The software for these new methods have been made available to the public. This project developed new hardware-based solutions for biomedical imaging problems, such as new methods for compressing deep learning models for biomedical image segementation and for training deep learning models on GPUs with limited memory. The work proposed a number of new schemes for efficient biomedical image annotation, largely reducing the heavy data annotation burden of biomedical experts for producing labeled data for deep learning model training, while maintaining the high performance of the deep learning models.

Seven Ph.D. students have been supported by this grant, and two students have graduated with Ph.D. degree, working in California on research and development of deep learning based computer vision applications.

This project produced two US utility patents, three US provisional patent applications, and one Patent CooperationTreaty (PCT) application.
